facts.text: Criminal Appeals Nos. 81 and 82 of 1958 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeals Nos. 81 and 82 of 1958.

facts.text: Appeals by special leave from Allahabad High Court judgment dated February 28, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 28, 1958, of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 1809 of 1957 and Referred No. 138 of 1957

facts.text: Allahabad High Court judgment in Criminal Appeal No. 1809 of 1957 and Referred No. 138 of 1957 arising from Sessions Trial No. 61 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and order dated November 28, 1957, of the Court of Sessions at Farrukhabad in Sessions Trial No. 61 of 1957.

facts.text: Sessions Court Farrukhabad judgment dated November 28, 1957 in Sessions Trial No. 61 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: of the Court of Sessions at Farrukhabad in Sessions Trial No. 61 of 1957.

facts.text: Appellants Tej Singh and Mizaji are father and son, Subedar is nephew of Tej Singh, Machal is cousin of Tej Singh, Maiku was servant of Tej Singh.

anchor.surface_text: Appellants Tej Singh and Mizaji are father and son, Subedar is a nephew of Tej Singh, Machal is Tej Singhs companysin and Maiku was a servant of Tej Singh.

facts.text: Appellants convicted under s. 302 read with s. 149 IPC, Mizaji sentenced to death, others to life imprisonment.

anchor.surface_text: They were all companyvicted under s. 302 read with s. 149 of the Indian Penal Code and except Mizaji who was sentenced to death, they were all sentenced to imprisonment for life.

facts.text: Tej Singh and Mizaji convicted under s. 148 IPC sentenced to 3 years RI, others under s. 147 to 2 years RI.

anchor.surface_text: They were also companyvicted of the offence of rioting and because Tej Singh and Mizaji were armed with a spear and a pistol respectively, they were companyvicted under s. 148

facts.text: All sentences to run concurrently, Mizaji's imprisonment to end after hanging.

anchor.surface_text: All the sentences were to run companycurrently but Mizajis term of imprisonment was to companye to an end after he is hanged .

facts.text: High Court confirmed convictions and sentences on appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Against this order of companyviction the appellants took an appeal to the High Court and both their companyvictions and sentences were companyfirmed.

facts.text: Offence committed on July 27, 1957 at about sunrise.

anchor.surface_text: The offence for which the appellants were companyvicted was companymitted on July 27, 1957, at about sunrise

facts.text: Field number 1096 known as Sukhna field recorded in revenue papers in name of Banwari as tenant-in-chief.

anchor.surface_text: the facts leading to the occurrence were that field number 1096 known as Sukhna field was recorded in the revenue papers in the name of Banwari who was recorded as in possession as tenant-in- chief

facts.text: Banwari mortgaged the plot to Lakhan Singh in 1949.

anchor.surface_text: Sometime in 1949 he mortgaged this plot of land to one Lakhan Singh.

facts.text: Mortgage redeemed in 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The mortgage was redeemed sometime in 1953.

facts.text: In 1952 field shown under cultivation of Rameshwar deceased, Ram Sarup uncle, Jailal brother, Sita Ram, Saddon.

anchor.surface_text: In 1952 this field was shown as being under the cultivation of Rameshwar, the deceased and four others persons, Ram Sarup who was the uncle of Rameshwar, Jailal his brother, Sita Ram and Saddon.

facts.text: Defence plea: possession shown as Banwari in 1954,1955,1956 but corrected in 1956 to Rameshwar et al, continued in 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The defence plea was that in the years 1954, 1955, 1956 possession was shown as that of Banwari. But if there were any such entries, they were companyrected in 1956 and possession was shown in the revenue papers as that of Rameshwar, and four others abovenamed. These entries showing cultivating possession of the deceased and four others were companytinued in 1957.

facts.text: Banwari sold field No. 1096 to Tej Singh on April 18, 1957; mutation application opposed by Rameshwar et al.

anchor.surface_text: On April 18, 1957, Banwari sold the field No. 1096 to Tej Singh appellant who made an application for mutation in his favour but this was opposed by the deceased and four other persons whose names were shown as being in possession.

facts.text: On July 27, 1957 early hours, five appellants came to field armed: Tej Singh spear, Mizaji pistol in dhoti fold, others lathis; brought plough, patela, bullocks.

anchor.surface_text: In the early hours of July 27, 1957, the five appellants came armed as above stated. Mizajis pistol is stated to have been in the fold  phent  of his dhoti. A plough and plank known as patela and bullocks were also brought.

facts.text: Field had sugarcane crop, jowar sown, rest uncultivated.

anchor.surface_text: The disputed field had three portions, in one sugarcane crop was growing, in the other Jowar had been sown and the rest had number been cultivated.

facts.text: Maiku started ploughing jowar field, overturning jowar; Tej Singh with spear kept watch.

anchor.surface_text: Maiku started ploughing the Jowar field and overturned the Jowar sown therein while Tej Singh with his spear kept watch.

facts.text: Bateshwar PW 7 informed Ram Sarup of the activity; Ram Sarup with Rameshwar, Jailal, Israel came unarmed to field.

anchor.surface_text: Bateshwar P. W. 7 seeing what was happening gave information of this to Ram Sarup who accompanied by Rameshwar, Jailal and Israel came to the Sukhna field but unarmed.

facts.text: Ram Sarup inquired why Tej Singh damaging field; Tej replied he purchased it; altercation ensued.

anchor.surface_text: Ram Sarup inquired of Tej Singh as to why he was damaging his field and Tej Singh replied that he had pur- chased the field and therefore would do what he was doing which led to an altercation.

facts.text: Mizaji, Subedar, Machal, Maiku came from cutting sugarcane; upon Tej Singh instigation, Mizaji fired pistol hitting Rameshwar who fell and died 1 hour later.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon, the four persons cutting the sugarcane crop i.e. Mizaji, Subedar, Machal and Maiku came to the place where Tej Singh was and upon the instigation of Tej Singh, Mizaji took out the pistol and fired which hit Rameshwar, who fell down and died I hour later.

facts.text: Accused fled after Rameshwar fell.

anchor.surface_text: The accused, after Rameshwar fell down, fled from the place.

facts.text: Ram Sarup, Jailal, Israel went to Nawabgunj police station; Ram Sarup made FIR at 7:30 a.m. naming all five accused.

anchor.surface_text: Ram Sarup, Jailal and Israel then went to the police station Nawabgunj and Ram Sarup there made the first information report at about 7-30 a. m., in which all the five accused were named.

facts.text: Accused not found initially; proceedings under ss. 87,88 CrPC; Subedar, Tej Singh, Machal, Maiku appeared in court Aug 3 1957, Mizaji Aug 14 1957.

anchor.surface_text: When the police searched for the accused they companyld number be found and proceedings were taken under ss. 87 and 88 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, but before any process was issued Subedar, Tej Singh and Machal and Maiku appeared in companyrt on August 3, 1957, and Mizaji on August 14, 1957, and they were taken into custody.

facts.text: Sessions Judge accepted prosecution story, found Ram Sarup in possession, appellants formed unlawful assembly with common object to take forcible possession even causing death.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Sessions Judge accepted the story of the prosecution and found Ram Sarup to be in possession of the field he also found that the appellants formed an unlawful assembly the companymon object of which was to take forcible possession of the field and to meet every eventuality even to the extent of causing death

facts.text: High Court held appellants members of unlawful assembly to take forcible possession, prepared to commit murder if necessary.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court on appeal held that the appellants were members of an unlawful assembly and had gone to the Sukhna field with the object of taking forcible possession and there is also numberdoubt that the accused had gone there fully prepared to meet any eventuality even to companymit murder

facts.text: Defence of accused: total denial of participation, suggested Rameshwar killed in dacoity at Ram Sarup house.

anchor.surface_text: The defence of the accused was a total denial of having participated in the occurence and as a matter of fact suggested that Rameshwar was killed in a dacoity which took place at the house of Ram Sarup.

anchor.surface_text: The first part of the section means that the offence companymitted in prosecution of the companymon object must be one which is companymitted with a view to accomplish the companymon object. It is number necessary that there should be a preconcert in the sense of a meeting of the members of the unlawful assembly as to the companymon object it is enough if it is adopted by all the members and is shared by all of them.

concepts.interpretation: First part: offence connected immediately with common object, no need for prior meeting, shared by all; second part if knew likely (not mere possibility); distinction between parts cannot be ignored.

arguments.court_reasoning: Sessions Judge and High Court accepted prosecution eyewitness evidence; Supreme Court upheld.

arguments.claim: Ram Sarup was in possession of the field; appellants formed unlawful assembly with common object to take forcible possession even to the extent of causing death if interfered with; murder in prosecution of common object.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Sessions Judge accepted the story of the prosecution and found Ram Sarup to be in possession of the field he also found that the appellants formed an unlawful assembly the common object of which was to take forcible possession of the field and to meet every eventuality even to the extent of causing death

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court agreed with findings on common object, weapons, conduct.

arguments.claim: Appellants were members of unlawful assembly to take forcible possession, fully prepared to commit murder if necessary; knew murder likely from weapons and conduct.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court on appeal held that the appellants were members of an unlawful assembly and had gone to the Sukhna field with the object of taking forcible possession and there is also no doubt that the accused had gone there fully prepared to meet any eventuality even to commit murder

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court confirmed applicability under s.149 first or second part based on weapons, conduct.

arguments.claim: High Court was not justified in inferring that other members of the appellants' party had knowledge of the pistol.

anchor.surface_text: For the appellants it was contended that the High Court was not justified in drawing the inference that other members of the party of the appellants had knowledge of the existence of the pistol.

arguments.court_reasoning: Father knew; circumstances justify inference for rest given relationship, arms.

arguments.claim: Common object of unlawful assembly was only to take forcible possession; murder neither committed in prosecution of common object nor known likely to be committed by members.

anchor.surface_text: It was argued on behalf of the appellants that the common object was to take forcible possession and that murder was committed neither in prosecution of the common object of the unlawful assembly nor was it such as the members of that assembly knew to be likely to be committed.

arguments.court_reasoning: Weapons (pistol, spear, lathis), conduct (collecting, threats 'finish all'), show prepared for murder or knew likely.

arguments.claim: Section 149 inapplicable as per Queen v. Sabid Ali (unlawful assembly for possession, sudden firing on resistance not in prosecution of object).

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellants relied on Queen v. Sabid Ali, and argued that s. 149 was inapplicable.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ome members of the assembly had previous knowledge that murder was likely to be companymitted. This section has been the subject matter of interpretat

arguments.court_reasoning: Distinguished facts; differing judicial opinions; clarified s.149 first part requires offence to accomplish object, no preconcert needed; second part knowledge beyond possibility.

arguments.claim: Conviction under s.302/149 not justified as per Chikkarange Gowda (composite charge mixing s.34/149, improper notice, common object only chastise).

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellants also relied on Chikkarange Gowda State of Mysore. In that case there were special circumstances which were sufficient to dispose of it.

arguments.court_reasoning: Special circumstances: improper composite charge, no separate intention specified, acquittal of actual killer; not applicable here.

arguments.claim: Appellants went to take possession quietly in absence of complainants, believed land theirs by right; not forcible.

anchor.surface_text: It was next argued that the appellants went to take possession in the absence of the complainants who were in possession and therefore the common object was not to take forcible possession but to quietly take possession of land which the appellants believed was theirs by right.

arguments.court_reasoning: Ongoing revenue proceedings opposed; armed with lethal weapons; divided but collected on resistance, threatened.

arguments.claim: Offence falls under first part of s.149: murder committed in prosecution of common object (forcible possession), connected immediately, shared by all, no preconcert needed.

anchor.surface_text: The first part of the section means that the offence committed in prosecution of the common object must be one which is committed with a view to accomplish the common object. It is not necessary that there should be a preconcert...

arguments.claim: Case falls under second part of s.149: members knew murder likely from weapons, conduct (armed group taking land).

anchor.surface_text: Even if the offence committed is not in direct prosecution of the common object of the assembly, it may yet fall under s. 149 if it can be held that the offence was such as the members knew was likely to be committed.

arguments.claim: Appellants prepared to commit murder if necessary (weapons, collected, threats 'finish all', instigation to fire).

anchor.surface_text: Can it be said in the circumstances of this case that in prosecution of the common object the members of the unlawful assembly were prepared to go to the extent of committing murder or they knew that it was likely to be committed?

arguments.court_reasoning: Testimony of Matadin, Hansraj on threats.

arguments.claim: Mizaji did not want to fire, hesitated until father asked; death penalty should not be imposed.
arguments.court_reasoning: Carried pistol to use in common object; shared fully; no mitigation in obeying father.

arguments.claim: All appellants guilty under s.149; Mizaji death, others life imprisonment appropriate.

anchor.surface_text: Other appellants being equally guilty under s. 149, Indian Penal Code, have been rightly sentenced to imprisonment for life.

arguments.claim: Tej Singh guilty of abetment of murder by instigating Mizaji.
Distinction between first and second parts of s.149 cannot be ignored; determine which applies per facts.

anchor.surface_text: In every case it would be an issue to be determined whether the offence committed falls within the first part of s. 149 as explained above or it was an offence such as the members of the assembly know to be likely to be committed...

holdings.text: The High Court was justified in inferring that the other members of the appellants' party had knowledge of the existence of the pistol carried by Mizaji.

anchor.surface_text: For the appellants it was contended that the High Court was not justified in drawing the inference that other members of the party of the appellants had knowledge of the existence of the pistol. There is nodoubt that on the evidence the father Tej Singh must have known that the son, Mizaji, had a pistol. And in the circumstances of this case the High Court cannot be said to have erroneously inferred as to the knowledge of the rest as to the possession of pistol by Mizaji.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Father knew; circumstances including family relationship and armed group justify inference for others.

holdings.text: The common object of the unlawful assembly was to take forcible possession of the Sukhna field.

anchor.surface_text: The question for decision is as to what was the common object of the unlawful assembly and whether the offence of murder was committed in prosecution of the common object or was such an offence as the members of the unlawful assembly knew was likely to be committed in prosecution of the common object. It was argued on behalf of the appellants that the common object was to take forcible possession and that murder was committed neither in prosecution of the common object of the unlawful assembly nor was it such as the members of that assembly knew to be ,.likely to be committed. That the common object of the unlawful assembly was to take forcible possession of the Sukhana field cannot be doubted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Undisputed based on facts of armed entry, ploughing despite opposition, recent purchase disputed in revenue proceedings.

holdings.text: The appellants were prepared to commit murder in prosecution of the common object or knew murder was likely to be committed, given weapons and conduct.

anchor.surface_text: Can it be said in the circumstances of this case that in prosecution of the common object the members of the unlawful assembly were prepared to go to the extent of committing murder or they knew that it was likely to be committed ? One of the members of the assembly Tej Singh was armed with a spear. His son Mizaji was armed with a pistol and others were carrying lathis. The extent to which the members of the unlawful assembly were prepared to go is indicated by the weapons carried by the appellants and by their conduct, their collecting where Tej Singh was and also the language they used at the time towards the complainants party.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Armed with pistol, spear, lathis; collected on resistance; threats to 'finish all'; testimony of Matadin and Hansraj accepted.

holdings.text: The murder was immediately connected with the common object; the case falls under s.149 IPC making all appellants guilty of murder under s.302.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Conduct shows preparation at any cost; immediate connection via threats and firing on resistance.

holdings.text: The distinction between the first and second parts of s.149 IPC cannot be ignored or obliterated; each case must determine which applies.

anchor.surface_text: The distinction between the two parts of s. 149, Indian Penal Code cannot be ignored or obliterated. In every case it would be an issue to be determined whether the offence committed falls within the first part of s. 149 as explained above or it was an offence such as the members of the assembly know to be likely to be committed in prosecution of the common object and falls within the second part.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation distinguishing 'in prosecution of common object' (first part, immediate connection to accomplish object) from 'knew likely' (second part, beyond mere possibility); references Sabid Ali opinions.

holdings.text: No preconcert or prior meeting required for first part of s.149 if common object adopted and shared by all members.

anchor.surface_text: The first part of the section means that the offence committed in prosecution of the common object must be one which is committed with a view to accomplish the common object. It is not necessary that there should be a preconcert in the sense of a meeting of the members of the unlawful assembly as to the common object it is enough if it is adopted by all the members and is shared by all of them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clarifies scope: offence to accomplish object; shared adoption suffices over formal meeting.

holdings.text: Tej Singh is guilty of abetment of murder.
The penalty of death was rightly imposed on Mizaji.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Carried pistol for use in common object; no mitigation in hesitation or obeying father.

holdings.text: The other appellants have been rightly sentenced to imprisonment for life under s.302 r/w s.149 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: Other appellants being equally guilty under s. 149, Indian Penal Code, have been rightly sentenced to imprisonment for life.

precedents.cited_proposition: Whether s.149 IPC applies when members of unlawful assembly go to take forcible possession of land and one fires upon resistance

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellants also relied on Chikkarange Gowde State of Mysore  2 . In that case there were special circumstances which were sufficient to dispose of it. The charge was a composite one mixing up common intention and common object under ss. 34 and 149

precedents.case_name: Chikkarange Gowda v. State of Mysore
precedents.cited_proposition: Applicability of s.302/149 IPC where charge mixes ss.34 and 149 and findings do not establish common object or knowledge of likelihood of murder
precedents.cited_holding: Conviction under s.302/149 not justified due to defective charge and High Court findings that common object was only to chastise, not murder

outcome.relief_summary: Convictions under s. 302 r/w s. 149, s. 148 and s. 147 IPC upheld. Death sentence for Mizaji and life imprisonment for other appellants confirmed as rightly imposed by courts below.

anchor.surface_text: For the appellants it was contended that the High Court was not justified in drawing the inference that other members of the party of the appellants had knowledge of the existence of the pistol. There is nodoubt that on the evidence the father Tej Singh must have known that the son, Mizaji, had a pistol. And in the circumstances of this case the High Court cannot be said to have erroneously inferred as to the knowledge of the rest as to the possession of pistol by Mizaji.

anchor.surface_text: The question for decision is as to what was the common object of the unlawful assembly and whether the offence of murder was committed in prosecution of the common object or was such an offence as the members of the unlawful assembly knew was likely to be committed in prosecution of the common object. It was argued on behalf of the appellants that the common object was to take forcible possession and that murder was committed neither in prosecution of the common object of the unlawful assembly nor was it such as the members of that assembly knew to be ,.likely to be committed. That the common object of the unlawful assembly was to take forcible possession of the Sukhana field cannot be doubted.

The question for decision is as to what was the common object of the unlawful assembly and whether the offence of murder was committed in prosecution of the common object or was such an offence as the members of the unlawful assembly knew was likely to be committed in prosecution of the common object. It was argued on behalf of the appellants that the common object was to take forcible possession and that murder was committed neither in prosecution of the common object of the unlawful assembly nor was it such as the members of that assembly knew to be ,.likely to be committed. anchor.surface_text: Can it be said in the circumstances of this case that in prosecution of the common object the members of the unlawful assembly were prepared to go to the extent of committing murder or they knew that it was likely to be committed ? One of the members of the assembly Tej Singh was armed with a spear. His son Mizaji was armed with a pistol and others were carrying lathis. The extent to which the members of the unlawful assembly were prepared to go is indicated by the weapons carried by the appellants and by their conduct, their collecting where Tej Singh was and also the language they used at the time towards the complainants party.

Can it be said in the circumstances of this case that in prosecution of the common object the members of the unlawful assembly were prepared to go to the extent of committing murder or they knew that it was likely to be committed ? One of the members of the assembly Tej Singh was armed with a spear. His son Mizaji was armed with a pistol and others were carrying lathis. The extent to which the members of the unlawful assembly were prepared to go is indicated by the weapons carried by the appellants and by their conduct, their collecting where Tej Singh was and also the language they used at the time towards the complainants party.

edges.explanation: Holding distinction between first and second parts of s.149 cannot be ignored addresses whether offence falls in first or second part.

anchor.surface_text: The distinction between the two parts of s. 149, Indian Penal Code cannot be ignored or obliterated. In every case it would be an issue to be determined whether the offence committed falls within the first part of s. 149 as explained above or it was an offence such as the members of the assembly know to be likely to be committed in prosecution of the common object and falls within the second part.

The distinction between the two parts of s. 149, Indian Penal Code cannot be ignored or obliterated. In every case it would be an issue to be determined whether the offence committed falls within the first part of s. 149 as explained above or it was an offence such as the members of the assembly know to be likely to be committed in prosecution of the common object and falls within the second part.

The first part of the section means that the offence committed in prosecution of the common object must be one which is committed with a view to accomplish the common object. It is not necessary that there should be a preconcert in the sense of a meeting of the members of the unlawful assembly as to the common object it is enough if it is adopted by all the members and is shared by all of them.

The first part of the section means that the offence committed in prosecution of the common object must be one which is committed with a view to accomplish the common object. It is not necessary that there should be a preconcert in the sense of a meeting of the members of the unlawful assembly as to the common object it is enough if it is adopted by all the members and is shared by all of them.
